content:
The "Veterans Success on Campus Act of 2016" allows the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide on-campus educational and vocational counseling for veterans. The Department of Veterans Affairs will offer on-campus educational and vocational counseling services for veterans at selected locations on college campuses. The selected institutions must provide suitable space for counseling services to be provided. The goal is to ensure maximum access for veterans seeking counseling. The Department of Veterans Affairs will provide on-campus counseling services for veterans at selected college campuses to ensure maximum access. The Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress on the counseling services provided, including counselor ratios, service descriptions, recommendations for improvement, and other relevant matters. The Department of Veterans Affairs will offer on-campus educational and vocational counseling services for veterans. The Department of Veterans Affairs will provide educational and vocational counseling services for veterans. Amendments to licensure and certification tests in title 38, United States Code, will pro-rate fees based on the actual test cost, and national tests will evaluate prior learning for course credit at higher learning institutions. These changes will apply to tests taken 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Modification of percentage increase in rates payable under Department of Veterans Affairs educational assistance programs. Amendments are made to adjust rates for fiscal years 2024 and 2025. 

SEC. 5. Extension of authority for Veterans' Advisory Committee on Education until December 31, 2021.

SEC. 6. Training for school certifying officials. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in consultation with State approving agencies, sets training requirements for school certifying officials at educational institutions with 20 or more students using VA educational assistance. Failure to meet requirements may result in course disapproval. The term "State approving agency" refers to a department or agency of a State designated under section 3671 of title 38, United States Code, responsible for certifying veteran enrollment at educational institutions. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON USE OF REPORTING FEES PAYABLE TO EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS AND JOINT APPRENTICESHIP TRAINING COMMITTEES. Section 3684(c) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to pay educational institutions or apprenticeship program sponsors a reporting fee in lieu of other compensation for required reports. The fee is calculated annually based on the number of eligible veterans or persons enrolled in specific chapters, with a higher rate for those whose assistance checks are sent to the institution for temporary custody and delivery. The reporting fee is paid to educational institutions or apprenticeship program sponsors for required reports. The fee is based on the number of eligible veterans or persons enrolled, with a higher rate for those whose assistance checks are sent to the institution for temporary custody. The fee is not subject to offset by the Secretary unless the institution's liability is uncontested or upheld by a court decree. The reporting fee paid to educational institutions or apprenticeship program sponsors is utilized solely for certifications required under specific chapters for veterans. For institutions with 75 or more enrollees, the fee cannot be used for the general fund and must be paid from appropriated readjustment benefits. SEC. 8. DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS INSPECTOR GENERAL HEIGHTENED SCRUTINY OF PROGRAMS OF EDUCATION. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must apply heightened scrutiny to any education program that has been found to use deceptive practices. Students enrolled in such programs must be notified of the scrutiny. The Secretary will monitor allegations of deceptive practices in education programs approved for GI Bill benefits and provide advice to individuals on obtaining transcripts and transferring credits. The Secretary will monitor deceptive practices in education programs approved for GI Bill benefits and provide advice on obtaining transcripts and transferring credits. Comparison Tool or similar websites of the Department will be utilized for this purpose. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of sections in the relevant chapter. Inspector General will scrutinize education programs. Department of Veterans Affairs can disapprove courses offered by institutions accused of deceptive practices. The Secretary can disapprove education courses if institutions violate regulations, with counseling services provided for affected individuals to transfer to another institution.
